title: Black man led by rope in Texas says arrest video made him feel shame
text:
A homeless black man who was led by rope through the streets of Texas by police on horseback says he was overcome with shame after watching video of his arrest.

Donald Neely's arrest for criminal trespass on August 3 in Galveston caused outrage after footage emerged of two mounted officers leading him down a street with a rope attached to his handcuffs.

The 43-year-old said he wasn't initially embarrassed when he was walking between the officers' horses but that changed after he saw his arrest on police body camera footage that was released publicly on Wednesday.

'It came back and hurt me because I did not know I was getting video recorded by the public. Now I feel embarrassed,' Neely told the Houston Chronicle.

Donald Neely's arrested for criminal trespass on August 3 in Galveston, Texas caused outrage after footage emerged of police leading him by rope

Neely, who has been living on the streets since 2016, has been diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia.

He said he hopes the image of him handcuffed and being led through the streets of Galveston will prompt a broader conversation about how police handle mentally ill suspects.

Footage shared online of the two officers leading Neely by rope - reminiscent of pictures showing slaves in chains - has sparked a wave of public outrage.

In the body cam video, one officer can be heard twice saying that leading Neely by rope down city streets would look 'bad'.

A Texas Rangers investigation determined the officers didn't break the law. The Galveston County Sheriff's Office also conducted a review.

Galveston Police Chief Vernon Hale, who is black, said on Friday that he is reviewing the sheriff's department report on the arrest to determine whether any further action will be taken against the two officers.

He said the officers could have handled Neely's arrest better but added that they did a good job of keeping Neely calm during the process.

Neely said he doesn't harbor any ill will toward the officers but he believes it's a waste of time and money to arrest him when he isn't harming anyone.

He has been arrested nearly 50 times, mostly for trespassing.

Neely's attorney, Julie Ketterman, said her client's treatment was unacceptable and she is considering filing a lawsuit alleging his civil rights were violated.

Before his arrest last month, Neely had repeatedly resisted his family's efforts to bring him home. But since then, he has begun piecing his life back together.

He entered a Houston treatment center for three weeks, moved in with his sister, Taranette, and her family, and is taking daily medication.

The oldest of five siblings, Neely moved with his family from Florida to Texas City during childhood and was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia at a young age.

He was treated as a problem child by the education system, shuffled in and out of classes for students with behavioral problems during high school, his sister said.

Neely dropped out of school and got caught up in petty crime.

Neely said he refuses to view his mental illness as a reason for shame.

'It's a title,' Neely said. 'It's not authentic. It's not going to stick. Every time they label me with a mental illness or as a paranoid schizophrenic, it rolls straight off.'
